#### Yudhishthira Maharaj, Parikshit Maharaj, Responsibilities of a King, Human Form of Life, Spiritual Guidance
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/XY4bYVfQ9Y8?t=50
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Human form of life means a life of responsibility, and the king ensures that people take advantage of this human form of life by becoming very responsible."
**Summary:** This segment discusses Yudhishthira Maharaj handing over the kingdom to Parikshit Maharaj, emphasizing the king's responsibility to guide citizens towards spiritual realization and the importance of human life for understanding the difference between temporary and permanent.

In this session we will be discussing from the 38th verse of the 15th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. स्वराट् पौत्रं बिनैनं आत्मनः सुसमं गुनैहि तोय नीव्याः पतिम् भूमेर् अभ्यसिंचत् गजाह्वये The meaning of this 38th verse is: Thereafter in the capital of Hastinapura he enthroned his grandson who was trained and equally qualified as the emperor and master of all land bordered by the seas. So here is the description of Yudhishthira Maharaj retiring from active household life and he is handing over charge of ruling the world to his trained and qualified grandson, Parikshit Maharaj. Parikshit Maharaj was the only surviving descendant of the Pandava family of the Kuru dynasty. Everyone else was killed in the battle of Kurukshetra. So Yudhishthira Maharaj handed over charge to Parikshit Maharaj and he handed over charge as the emperor and master of all lands bordered by the seas, the whole world. He handed over charge of ruling the entire world to Parikshit Maharaj. Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, "The total land on the earth bordered by the seas was under the subjugation of the king of the Kuru dynasty, the king of Hastinapura." This is the arrangement. The emperor of the world ruled from the place called Hastinapura. Hastinapura is modern day Delhi. Elsewhere Srila Prabhupada explains. So the capital was always in Hastinapura of the rulers of the entire world. There was subordination. There were subordinate kings and they had their smaller jurisdiction of province or state or some small kingdom, but they were always subordinate to the emperor. So that was actually the system, that there were different territorial kings who were protected by the emperor against any invasion by rogues and thieves and dacoits etc. So they used to rule the citizens very nicely according to the scriptural directions, according to the kshatriya dharma, the perfect system of administration given in the perfect scriptures, coming from the perfect source, the supreme personality of Godhead. So Srila Prabhupada further says, "Maharaja Yudhishtira trained his grandson Maharaj Pariksit, who was equally qualified in state administration in terms of the king's obligation to the citizens." Earlier Srila Prabhupada elaborately explained what were the obligations of the king to the citizens. The king had to essentially ensure that all the necessities were provided for the citizens so that the citizens can actually become responsible for preparing themselves to go back to Godhead after having achieved or after having received a human form of life. So human form of life means a life of responsibility and the king ensures that people take advantage of this human form of life by becoming very responsible, not that they are busy simply earning money or busy with some material activities, busy with some sense gratification, all under the influence of the illusory energy for some temporary effects. No. Human being means should understand the difference between the temporary and permanent, material and spiritual, body and soul, matter and spirit. Clear difference or distinction should be made and the human being has the developed consciousness or intelligence or brain substance to actually be able to do this.

The material energy in its dormant condition, inactive state, is Avyakta. And when it is activated at the beginning of creation by the glance of Mahavishnu, it becomes Mahat-Tatva, the state in which the material energy becomes activated. Activated means the three gunas become, start working. And those three gunas, they interact with the Mahat-Tatva and produce so many material elements. And those material elements are combined to form this variegated material universe. Different products, different material elements, different objects, and different bodies, everything. So now, whatever we see in our material vision is nothing but the combination of different material objects or products. But the living entity is different from such material products. They are completely different from the body, from the mind, from the intelligence, from the false ego, from the material objects, varieties of material objects.

Srila Prabhupada says Draupadi was the most beautiful daughter of King Drupada, and when she was a young girl, almost all the princess desired her hand. The Kshatriyas, they want to marry the most beautiful princess of their time in their, in the neighborhood. So it was well known in the different parts of this Bharat Varsha during the time of Draupadi that this daughter of Drupada, she was the most beautiful princess of her time. And when Drupada announced that she is going to be married to the prince who can actually successfully pass a test, then so many princess came. So here Srila Prabhupada explains something confidential, that Drupada Maharaj decided to hand over his daughter to Arjuna only. This was Drupada's desire. He wanted to marry his daughter Draupadi only to Arjuna, and therefore Drupada contrived a peculiar way. Drupada is very intelligent, because it's not explained in the purport by Srila Prabhupada, the details are there in the Mahabharata, that Drupada actually could have directly approached Arjuna and expressed his desire to marry his daughter to Arjuna, but Arjuna was reportedly killed in a fire accident. This was the time when Duryodhana was plotting to kill the Pandavas, and Duryodhana along with the support and the encouragement by his father Dhritarashtra, Duryodhana built a palace, separate palace for the Pandavas in another place, and that palace was made of combined combustible materials, shellac, and the Pandavas were told by Dhritarashtra, you don't have to share the palace in Hastinapura with the Kauravas, you go and stay separately in a beautiful palace that I have specially arranged to be built for you, and you stay there comfortably. Now Pandavas, they came to know through some secret messages, basically from Vidura, the Pandavas came to know that this was a plot to kill them by setting fire after they went to that new palace and in that way burn them alive. This was also another secret not known to Duryodhana or Dhritarashtra or any of the Kauravas. So when Pandavas agreed to go, Dhritarashtra thought now somehow eliminate the Pandavas. So then the Pandavas actually escaped after going there, and even though the palace was set on fire, the people thought Pandavas were living inside, and they were very, very unhappy that the Pandavas were killed in apparently a fire accident, and externally the Kauravas who knew the real reason why the Pandavas were sent there to be killed alive, burnt alive, so they externally expressed some sorrow, very unfortunate the Pandavas were burnt alive, some accident, but actually practically nobody knew that the Pandavas had escaped. Drupada was doubtful whether the Pandavas were really killed in that fire accident. In this session we will be discussing from the 8th verse of the 15th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. This chapter is entitled the Pandavas retire timely. The events leading to the Pandavas retiring from their kingly duties is being described in this chapter. And this Krishna Mantra Prasurtyamantra was a very powerful king of Magada, and the history of his birth and activities was also very interesting. His father, King Brihadratha, was also a very prosperous and powerful king of Magada, but he had no son, although he married two daughters of the king of Kashi. Being disappointed in not getting a son from either of the two queens, the king, along with his wives, left Kashi home to live in the forest for austerities. But in the forest, he was blessed by one great Rishi to have his son, and that Rishi gave him one mango to be eaten by the queens. The queens did so and were very soon pregnant. The king was very happy to see the queens bearing children, but when the right time approached, the queens delivered one child in two parts, one from each of the queens' wombs. The two parts were thrown in the forest where a great she-demon used to live, and she was glad to have some delicate alnya flesh and blood from the newly born child. Out of curiosity, she joined the two parts, and the child became complete and regained life. The king was in a haste. He thought the queens have delivered two parts which are not complete. He thought they are useless. Both the queens have delivered something which is incomplete. So, they simply discarded the parts. But when the she-demon joined the two parts, they became complete and regained life. The child became complete and regained life because the child was born due to the blessing of the rishi in the forest. The rishi blessed that the king have only one child through the two queens, one child. Becoming common, the class 4 queen came out. So, therefore, the she-demon was known as 'jara', that was her name, who lived in that forest where the king had retired, and being compassionate on the childless king, she went to the king and presented him with the nice child. Instead of, she presented the king with the child. The king was very pleased with the she-demon and wanted to reward her according to her desire. The she-demon expressed her desire that the child be named after her. And thus, the child was surnamed Jarasandha, or one who was joined by Jara, the she-demon. Sandha means to join.

#### Maharaj Pariksit's conquests, earthly planet divisions, Dvipas, Varshas, Jambudvipa

**Key Quote:** "Maharaj Pariksit then conquered all parts of the earthly planet...and exacted tributes from their respective rulers."
**Summary:** This segment explains Maharaj Pariksit's conquests and the division of the earth into Dvipas and Varshas, focusing on Jambudvipa.

The twelfth verse. Bhadrashvam ketum alamcha bharatam chottaran kuram kim purushadini varshani vijitya jagrihe balim. So these are names of different parts of the earthly planet that Pariksit conquered. So in the translation. The translation is as follows. Maharaj Pariksit then conquered all parts of the earthly planet, Bhadrashva, Ketumala, Bharata, the Northern Kuru, Kim Purusha, etc., and exacted tributes from their respective rulers. The system was the subordinate kings had to pay a portion of the tax they collected from their citizens to the emperor. So Maharaj Pariksit went to different parts of his kingdom, that means the whole world, earthly planet, and exacted the taxes from the respective rulers. So Srila Prabhupada gives a brief description of these different parts that were the parts of the earth, as divided during the time of Maharaj Pariksit. So first of all in the purport he describes Bhadrashva Varsha. It is a tract of land near Meru Parvata, and it extends from Gandhamadana Parvata to the salt water ocean. There is a description of this Varsha in the Mahabharata, in the Bhishma Parva 7th chapter verses 14 to 18. Mahabharata is the history of greater India. So it is called Itihasa. It is compiled by Vyasadeva. So Srila Prabhupada is quoting from this, that this Bhadrashva Varsha is described in this particular portion of the Mahabharata. The description was narrated by Sanjaya to Dhritarashtra about this Bhadrashva Varsha. Maharaj Yudhishthira also conquered this Varsha, and thus the province was included within the jurisdiction of his empire. Maharaj Pariksit was formally declared to be the emperor of all lands ruled by his grandfather, but still he had to establish his supremacy while he was out of his capital to exact tribute from such states. The king is not simply a namesake king. He has got his power to rule, and he challenges the subordinate kings. If they accept his supremacy then there is no fighting. Otherwise there is a battle fought between the two kings, and whoever is victorious becomes the ruler. Ketumala Varsha. Another part of his kingdom. This earth planet is divided into seven Dvipas by seven oceans, and the central Dvipa called Jambudvipa is divided into nine Varshas, or parts, by eight huge mountains. See. The whole earth planet, even as we know it today, there are so many oceans, Pacific Ocean, Indian Ocean, and Atlantic Ocean, like that. So there are seven oceans dividing the earth planet into seven islands. The land mass between two oceans, surrounded by water is called an island.

#### Vedic culture, welcome addresses, Krishna Samhita
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/d30rNAe9YZg?t=343
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The subject matter of those welcome addresses was Krishna. This is the most important point."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that the Vedic culture involves welcoming great personalities with addresses focused on Krishna, highlighting that Srimad Bhagavatam is also known as Krishna Samhita.

So Srila Prabhupada explains a significant point to be noted in these verses. In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "Kings and great personalities of the state are presented with welcome addresses." This is the Vedic culture. This is a system from time immemorial, and Maharaj Parikshit, since he was one of the well-known emperors of the world, was also presented with addresses of welcome in all parts of the world as he visited those places. He was a very great emperor, so naturally people would welcome him. A great personality is welcomed when he visits a certain place. People who are conversant with his greatness, they will glorify him for the benefit of everyone else. The subject matter of those welcome addresses was Krishna. This is the most important point. How is it that Krishna is the subject matter of all those welcome addresses when Parikshit was travelling in different parts of his kingdom? Because Parikshit was a great devotee of Krishna. Parikshit's forefathers who were ruling the earth planet, the Pandavas, they were also great devotees of Krishna. So whether somebody glorifies Krishna or Krishna's pure devotees, always the subject matter of such glorification is Krishna. That's why the Bhagavatam, which contains nothing but the glorification of Krishna and his pure devotees, is also called Krishna Samhita. That means it is that special Vedic literature, Samhita means Vedic literature, which is exclusively devoted to descriptions of the glorifications of Krishna.

That is the speciality of the Bhagavatam. So therefore, it is called Krishna Samhita. It is a very special literature. So Srila Prabhupada clarifies, "Krishna means Krishna and his eternal devotees as the king means the king and his confidential associates." A king is never alone. When a king travels, he has got his confidential associates. Similarly, Krishna is never alone. Krishna is always with his confidential associates, who are all his devotees. All are his devotees. Krishna is the one and only one Supreme Lord, and everyone else, especially in the spiritual world, everyone else is a devotee. Actually, everyone in the material world also is a devotee of Krishna, but in the material world, people are forgetful of their devotional relationship with Krishna. That is the difference between the spiritual world and the material world. So Srila Prabhupada says, "Krishna and his unalloyed devotees cannot be separated, and therefore, glorifying the devotee means glorifying the Lord and vice versa." So glorification of devotee means it is nothing but glorification of Krishna only, because the object of the devotion of the devotees is Krishna only and nobody else. So when Shastras say Bhakti, Bhakti refers to devotion towards Krishna only and not devotion towards some other material personality, some other object of glorification.

If she knows Krishna is the supreme lord, where is the question of feeding Krishna? If Krishna is the supreme lord, he never becomes hungry, he is never in need of any food. He is the one who is supplying everybody. He is completely self-satisfied. He is full in himself. He is not in need of any food. He never gets hungry. So, the service is simply for the sake of loving reciprocation between the lord and his pure devotees.

Please understand, when scriptures say we are servants of Krishna, the concept of servant of Krishna is not like the concept of servant in the material world. Never mistakenly think that servant means servant like in the material world. No. In the spiritual world, all positions are absolute positions. Prabhupada explains this in another place. The servant is the master. The master is the servant. There is no difference. What is the meaning of that? Like Krishna demonstrated, before the battle of Kurukshetra, Krishna is the lord, or playing the role of the lord, and Arjuna is playing the role of the subordinate to the lord. But on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, Krishna agreed to become the chariot driver of Arjuna, and Arjuna ordered Krishna, please take my chariot between the two armies, so that I can see with whom I have to fight. He is ordering Krishna. Krishna says, okay, according to your order, I will take the chariot between the two armies. So, this is the kind of reciprocation between the lord and his devotees.

So this symbolic representation of the condition of human society reflected in the condition of the cow, the representative of mother earth, the cow. And even the condition of the bull, that will be described in the next verse, the condition of the bull. So dharma is inquiring from mother earth, madam addressing Bhadre. This is a respectful way of addressing a lady in the samsara. In Sanskrit language, Bhadre, madam. Are you not hale and hearty? Are you not keeping good health? Are you not happy? Why are you covered with the shadow of grief? That means not only is mother earth unhappy, but she is unhappy about something which seems like it is a cause for distress or unhappiness. Continues to linger for a long time. It's not something which comes and immediately goes away. It's not like a pinprick. That momentarily there is some pain and after the cause for the pinprick is removed then the pain is gone. It's not like that. You are covered with the shadow of grief. And it appears by your face that you have become black. That means the pain has been there. The problem of this cause for the pain has been there, and your face has become black because you have been suffering for quite some time, a good length of time. Are you suffering from some internal disease? And what is the cause of your pain? Why are you suffering? Some internal disease? Is there some disease that has afflicted you? Or are you thinking of some relative who is away in a distant place? You are separated from your relative, and you are not able to live together happily. You are separated, and you are not able to actually be together due to some reason.

In this session, we will be discussing from two verses, the 23rd and the 24th verses of the 16th chapter of the Shri Advaitha Gadadhara. This is the 16th chapter of the first canto of Shri Madbhagavatam. The 23rd verse first: Yadva Amba Te Bhuri Bharaavatara Krataavatarasya Hare Dharitri Antarhitasya Smarati Vishrishta Karmaani Nirvana Vilambitani. The meaning of this 23rd verse is, "O Mother Earth, the Supreme Personality of Godhead Hari incarnated Himself as Lord Shri Krishna just to unload Your heavy burden. All His activities here are transcendental and they cement the path of liberation. You are now bereft of His presence. You are probably now thinking of those activities and feeling sorry in their absence." So, one more reason for Mother Earth to be aggrieved, feeling that grief, is because the Kali Yuga began after Krishna's disappearance, after Krishna wound up His pastimes on the earth. So, as long as Krishna was present, there was no possibility of any evil influence of any sort. And not only that, the Supreme Lord Himself incarnated to reduce the burden of the earth, which was overburdened by demoniac persons posing as kings. And as long as Krishna was present, His activities were all completely transcendental. And because of that, there was no possibility of any bad influence. So, in the absence of Krishna, those transcendental activities are not there anymore. And maybe Dharma is asking Mother Earth, maybe you are feeling sorry in the absence of Krishna and His transcendental activities.

**Summary:** The speaker explains that despite not needing to, Krishna voluntarily accepts responsibilities in his pastimes, giving the example of Krishna as a cowherd boy in Vrindavan, diligently caring for 108 groups of cows.

No. Still, he accepts voluntary responsibilities in displaying different roles in his transcendental pastimes. See, Krishna has nothing to do but doesn't mean he is inactive. He is active in performing his lila, his transcendental pastimes, divya lila. And those transcendental pastimes are always performed in his association with his pure devotees, and he accepts different roles in those pastimes. Prabhupada gives an example. As a boy in Vrindavan, he was playing the part of a cowboy, Gopalam. As a son of Nanda Maharaj, he discharged responsibility perfectly. He would dutifully go cowherding in the forest, take the cows for grazing, and he would go with his friends and he would bring back the cows after they finished grazing in the evening before sunset. So he would supervise the milking of the cows and he would ensure that the cows have all properly returned. He would count the groups of cows. There were 108 groups of cows Krishna was taking care of. It's very interesting, this number 108. We chant 108 times the Hare Krishna mantra in one mala, one round we say. The beads which we use for chanting japa, counting and chanting japa, there are 108 beads. So where is this number 108 coming from? One of the reasons this 108 number is fixed is because Krishna in his transcendental pastime of cowherding in Vrindavan when he appeared 5000 years back, he used to take 108 groups of cows for cowherding after he grew up. And when Krishna returns with those cows, he will count the number of groups that have come back when each group he calls and they come near Krishna and Krishna directs them to enter their particular, what do you say, cow shelter, cow pen, the particular designated area where the cows will stay. So he would count the groups, 108 groups he used to take and ensure that all the groups of cows have come back. It was a huge number. So he would count. And for that Krishna had a string of 108 pearls, a mala made of 108 pearls and he would count on them how many have come back. So when all the 108 have been counted, then yes, all the cows have come back. So he would do, my point is that he would do his duty responsibly as a son of Nanda Maharaj, who was a cowherd, a king of the cowherds.

You would have heard this many times. Krishna's feet are described as lotus feet because His feet are always resting on the lotus flower. So there is a certain honey available in the lotus flower, and that honey is what the devotees are accustomed to tasting when they take shelter of Krishna's lotus feet. That's why devotees are attached to Krishna's lotus feet, and that honey is as relishable as nectar. Therefore constantly the devotees want to be sheltered by Krishna's lotus feet. And that's why it is said devotees are accustomed to licking up the honey available from the lotus feet of the Lord. So to take shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord means to be engaged always in a relationship with topics of devotional service to Krishna. That is the meaning of taking shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord. I will stop here. Thank you very much.

So this being the case, Vyasadeva is advised by Narada, describe the science of God by directly relating his transcendental activities. They are very attractive, they are wonderful, they work within the depths of the heart of conditioned souls. Even those who have no understanding, no interest, they are materially attached, even such people, some or the other, if they hear this subject matter describing exclusively the transcendental activities of Krishna, then that sound vibration enters their ears, penetrates the heart, and cleanses the heart of desire for material enjoyment. This is already described in the second chapter.

**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes the lack of lasting satisfaction in material pursuits and provides examples of Bharat Maharaj and Chitraketu to illustrate that even those who fall down from devotional service are not lost.

It has nothing to do with soul happiness, soul satisfaction. Deep within, there is no satisfaction. Even if one is getting some material pleasure or material enjoyment or material happiness, deep within there is nothing that is worthwhile that one can experience. So, here it is said that there are instances in history of somebody who performed pure devotional service and fell down. There is an instance of one Bharat Maharaj. He performed, he gave up his kingdom and went to a holy place, and he was practicing pure devotional service. And then, towards the end of his life, he became attached to a deer, and he died thinking of the deer. So, he took birth, next birth, as a deer. But, because he had done pure devotional service, the Lord was kind enough to give him memory of what he did in his previous life. In the body of a deer, he was able to remember. And in that body of a deer, he was associating with saintly persons and hearing their discourses. He was not interested in eating or sleeping or nothing, even in the body of a deer. Similarly, there is an instance of Chitraketu who actually committed some offense at the feet of Shiva, and he fell down. But, next life, he was delivered. He realized his mistake, and he was delivered. Next life, even though he took birth as a demon, in the body of a demon, not as a demon, in the body of a demon, he was delivered, completely delivered. He got ultimate liberation. He was given memory by the Supreme Lord. So, there is no loss if one falls down. But, if one does occupational duties without doing pure devotional service, there is no gain at all. I will stop here. Thank you very much.

Impersonalists actually have no proper understanding of Vedanta philosophy, because they start with an assumption, even though unjustified, that ultimately, the Absolute Truth is impersonal. But, actually, the Absolute Truth has got three features. Impersonal feature is just one of the preliminary understanding of the Absolute Truth. There are two other features, the Paramatma feature and the Bhagavan feature. So, this Paramatma feature and the Bhagavan feature are completely mis-doubted by the impersonalists. Therefore, their understanding of Vedanta, is not complete. It is imperfect. It is incomplete, and it is misleading also, that ultimately, the Absolute Truth is impersonal. No. The Absolute Truth is the personality of Godhead. Therefore, Vedantavadis, refers to the pure devotees of the Supreme Lord, who have full understanding of all the three features of the Absolute Truth. Such Vedantavadis are also called as Bhaktivedantas. They are impartial in distributing the transcendental knowledge of devotional service. To them, nobody is enemy, nobody is friend. Nobody is educated, nobody is uneducated. They don't make distinctions based on all these type of characteristics. Nobody is favorable, nobody is unfavorable.

#### Krishna consciousness, dedication, proprietorship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/oKbQ-2nrDPw?t=159

**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on how to remember Krishna in all aspects of life, stating that Krishna should be considered the proprietor in every sphere, even in Vedic rites involving demigods.

So how does it actually work? Srila Prabhupada elaborates this in the purport. He says, an expert devotee of the Lord can mold his life in such a way that while performing all kinds of duties, either for this or the next life, he can constantly remember the Lord's name, fame, qualities, etc. So it is a question of molding one's life in a particular way that is enabling one to remember the Lord's name, qualities, pastimes, etc. The order of the Lord is distinctly there in the Bhagavad Gita. What is that order? One should work only for Lord Krishna in all spheres of life. In every sphere of life the Lord should be situated as the proprietor. According to Vedic rites, even in the worship of some demigods like Indra, Brahma, Saraswatthi, Ganesha, the system is that in all circumstances the representation of Vishnu must be there as Yajneshwara or the controlling power of such sacrifices.

#### supreme enjoyer, proprietorship, association with Krishna
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/oKbQ-2nrDPw?t=245
**Verse References:** BG 5.29
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Vishnu is the supreme lord of all the demigods."
**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes that Vishnu is the supreme lord and that all activities should be offered to Krishna, the supreme enjoyer, referencing Bhagavad Gita 5.29 and explaining that associating with Krishna's name and fame is associating with Krishna himself.

So, sacrifice to demigods also involves the representation of Vishnu as Yajneshwara. He is the supreme lord of all sacrifices. It is recommended that a particular demigod be worshipped for a particular purpose, as far as Karmakanda section of the Vedas is concerned. But still, the presence of Vishnu is compulsory in order to make the function proper, because the fact is, Vishnu is the supreme lord of all the demigods. Apart from such demigods, there are other demigods as well. Apart from such Vedic duties, even in our ordinary dealings, for example, in our business or profession or in our household affairs, we must consider that the result of all activities must be given over to the supreme enjoyer Lord Krishna. In the Bhagavad Gita, Lord Krishna has declared himself to be the supreme enjoyer of everything, the supreme proprietor of every planet and the supreme friend of all beings. This is a famous verse in the 5th chapter, 29th verse: bhoktaram yajnatapasam sarva-loka-maheshwaram suradam sarva-bhutanam jnatvamam shanti-mrcchati. So therefore, no one else but Lord Shri Krishna can claim to be the proprietor of everything within his creation. A pure devotee remembers this constantly and in doing so, he repeats the transcendental name, fame and qualities of the Lord, which means that he is constantly in touch with Lord Krishna. Now the Lord is identical with his name, fame, etc.

Now these four expansions are described as Vasudeva and Sankarsana are on the middle left and right. Pradyumna is on the right of Sankarsana and Aniruddha is on the left of Vasudeva. Now, as far as the four classes of bad men are concerned, they are also described in the Bhagavad Gita. The first category of bad men that are described, those who are simply addicted to the mode of progressive fruity work. Fruity work means they have to do some work in which they get some results for their material enjoyment, material pleasure, material gain. That is called fruity work. So, there are people who are addicted to progressive fruity work and they keep on doing this, and as a result, they are subjected to the accompanying miseries. Nothing in this material world, any material work done, is always accompanied by miseries. You cannot say, I will do something and I want only pleasure. No, not possible. Always there is pleasure and pain, or enjoyment and suffering. Sukha and dukkha are two sides of the same coin. Two sides of the same coin, material activity, fructive activity. So, this is the first class of bad men. The second class of bad men are those who are simply addicted to vicious work, sinful activities. For what? For sense gratification, for sense satisfaction. And naturally they suffer the consequences because they are outright engaging in sinful activity. They have to suffer. Sooner or later, they have to suffer. And the third class of bad men are those who are materially advanced in knowledge, but they suffer. In spite of being advanced in knowledge, they suffer because they do not have the sense to acknowledge the authority of the Almighty Supreme Lord. So, what happens? The effect of their knowledge is stolen away by the illusory energy: Māyayā pahṛtaṁ jñānam. And the fourth class of bad men, those who are known as atheists and who therefore purposely hate the very name of God,

Are losing out is the valuable human life, the time we can spend in this human form of life into searching out the vital necessity of this human form of life. What is that? Inquiry into the absolute truth. In just three words in Vedanta Sutra, the whole thing is summarized: Athato Brahma Jijnasa. Vital necessity of life. Inquire into what is spirit. What is Brahman or who is God. Or who you are. Inquire into this. Without making this inquiry, human life is completely wasted. All the developed intelligence, the ability to ask fundamental questions and try to get meaningful answers, this opportunity is lost. It's a greatest loss for a human being. In the evolution of the consciousness through different species of life in this material world, the human form of life is the most evolved, developed state of consciousness. So, therefore, it is very well known human being is a rational animal, can think, can contemplate, can inquire, can learn, can teach, can do so many things with this developed intelligence, developed consciousness. So, the most important inquiry, the most important inquiry is inquiry about spirit, inquiry about God, inquiry about spiritual reality. That's called Brahma Jijnasa. And that is the most important part of a Vedic knowledge.

He passed through different kinds of places, and as it will be explained in the next verse, it is the duty of a sanyasi, a renunciant, or one dedicated to spiritual life, to actually travel through different tracts of land which are all the creation of the supreme lord in this material world, and none of such places have any attraction for a serious spiritualist like Narada. There is no attraction. He is passing through reservoirs of gold, silver, copper, but he has no attraction for them, neither is he attracted to a beautiful place filled with clear water and lotus flowers so beautiful that it is fit for the heavenly inhabitants, singing birds, beautiful bees. So somebody serious about spiritual life will never be attracted to any place which is meant for satisfying the senses. So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains it is the duty of a mendicant. Mendicant literally means a beggar, but it is taken in the sense of a spiritualist who lives a very simple life by being dedicated for spiritual practice, and for maintaining his body he simply begs for some little food from a householder. So such a mendicant is called a parivrajaka acharya. Parivrajaka means he is travelling constantly, wandering, and acharya means he is teaching. What is he teaching? He is teaching spiritual subject matter. He is awakening householders who are lost in material way of life to remind them about their spiritual goal in life. So he enlightens them, and on the plea of begging he goes to their house, but his real purpose of going to the house of a householder is not for begging, it is for enlightening them spiritually. Of course, in the Vedic culture, the householders welcome a sanyasi or a travelling mendicant or a transcendentalist. They welcome him home because they know that he brings in all auspiciousness, but the real purpose of a sanyasi is not to beg. So just to satisfy some householders, he may take a little food, may take, may not take, but his main purpose is how to enlighten the householder in spiritual subject matter which is the prime necessity for every human being.

Briefly I will just mention what are the stages of sanyas. Kutichaka is when one decides to renounce connection with family members, leaves home, but not yet practiced how to maintain himself independently, so he builds a cottage outside his village and he receives food from home. He is cut off from the family members, social interaction, but as far as his food requirement is concerned, it is taken care of by the family, former family members. When he is practiced in that way, then he realizes how he can actually maintain himself very easily by begging a little from many different houses, so nobody will feel a burden for weeding one person a little bit, collecting little, little from many houses, then nobody feels the burden and the person is very easily able to get his necessity of daily food, and so that's called bahudhaka, the second stage of sanyas where one is not dependent only on his one home, the former purvashram family residence, but begs little from the different people of the village outside which he is staying, and in that way very easily he maintains himself, his requirement of food. Then when he becomes further well established in sanyas, then he starts actually travelling. Travelling is for gaining strength of mind, faith in God, and enlighten the inhabitants as he is passing through different towns, villages, or settlements, human settlements like that. So these three things are particularly mentioned here: travelling alone, travelling alone to become fearless because a sanyasi knows that God is in my heart and he is my top most well wisher, he is my protector, he is my maintainer. Only due to illusion somebody may think that I have to depend on somebody else or something else outside of me. Actually one's dependence should be on the supreme lord seated in the heart who is always accompanying every person and is providing, maintaining, is actually taking care of the well being. It is only this supreme lord who does so. This is the purpose of a sanyasi.

#### transcendental form of the Lord, mind's desire, mental incongruities, Narada Muni's experience
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xoI1iFCIR8g?t=58
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire and at once erases all mental incongruities."
**Summary:** This segment explains the meaning of the verse, focusing on how the transcendental form of the Lord satisfies the mind and removes mental incongruities, as experienced by Narada Muni.

In this session, we will be discussing from the 18th verse of the 6th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: रूपं भगवतो यत्तन मनकान्तं शुचापहं अपश्यन सहत सोतस्थे वैक्लव्या दुर्मना इवा. The meaning of this verse is: "The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire and at once erases all mental incongruities. Upon losing that form, I suddenly got up, being perturbed, as is usual, when one loses that which is desirable." So, Srila Nargumuni is explaining his experience to Vyasa Deva from his previous life. He began meditation. He had a glimpse of the Lord, and he became overjoyed with ecstasy. Suddenly, he lost that form. So then, after losing sight of that form, after getting a brief glimpse of darshan of that form of the Lord in the heart, Nargumuni is describing what was the kind of loss that he really felt when he lost sight of the Lord. The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire. The mind is the center of all the senses, and the mind is driving the senses towards sense objects, looking for something. What is that something that each one of us is looking for? It is actually Krishna. Everyone is looking for Krishna, having forgotten Him, and also desiring to get back that which we have lost. The most desirable, the most beautiful, the most wonderful, the dear most, the dearest, we have lost that, so we are looking for that. So therefore, when we actually get darshan of the transcendental form of the Lord, then immediately our mind's desire is completely satisfied. And also, all the mental incongruities are erased, means in the mind we settle for something when we don't get what we are really looking for, and we think maybe this can satisfy me, but then we find something else which may be relatively either better or more beautiful or more pleasing for the mind, again it creates in the mind a kind of complex situation that maybe this is what I was looking for, no no no, this is not what I was looking for. So there are so many mental incongruities essentially established through contact with so many other forms other than the form of the Lord, so all these incongruities in the mind are completely erased when we actually get darshan of the form of the Lord.

#### Narada Muni's experience, form of the Lord, material vs. spiritual form, limitations of material vision, Nirakar
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xoI1iFCIR8g?t=304
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Nirakar means the Lord does not have a material form."
**Summary:** This segment discusses Narada Muni's experience of seeing the Lord's form, contrasting it with the common understanding of God being formless (Nirakar), and clarifying that Nirakar means the Lord doesn't have a material form, but a transcendental one, which cannot be seen with material eyes.

And that's what Narad Muni is describing here. So he says, "I lost that form which was completely satisfying to my mind, which erased the form of the Lord, which erased all my mental incongruities, that form I lost." And suddenly, on losing the form, all of a sudden I lost that form, then I became very much perturbed in my mind, and that is to be expected because when somebody loses something which is very, very desirable, then how do they feel? That's how I felt. So, Shrila Prabhupada makes a very important point in the purport here that the Lord is not formless, is experienced by Narad Muni. A widely prevalent understanding about God is that God is formless, Nirakar. Nirakar is one of the terms that is used to describe God. It is one of the terms that is used to describe the Lord's features, but we should carefully understand what this Nirakar means. Nirakar means the Lord does not have a material form. He doesn't have a form made of flesh and blood and skin and bones. No, He doesn't have such a form. He has a transcendental form. He has a completely spiritual form. That form cannot be seen with these ordinary eyes. These eyes are suitable only for seeing some material forms. Even material forms which are very big we cannot see. Material forms which are too close to the eye we cannot see. We cannot see even our own eyelids. We can't see something very small. We can't see if there is no light to see a particular object or a form. So, these eyes have got limitations. In any case, even if we overcome all kinds of limitations of this eye by some mechanical means, material means, still, spiritual form can never be seen by any material adjustment even for these eyes. You cannot see spiritual form with material vision, even making adjustments.

#### purity, material contamination, modes of nature
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/TqNMFlPuMuw?t=54
**Verse References:** BG 10.12-13
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So there is no trace of a tinge of materiality in this person."
**Summary:** The Lord is completely pure and free from material contamination, unlike us who are influenced by the illusory energy, leading to a material conception of self and the world.

In this session we will be discussing from the first canto, 6th chapter, 21st verse of the Srimad Bhagavatam. हन्तास्मिन् जन्मनी भवान् मामाम् द्रष्टुम् इहार्हती अविपक्व कशायाणाम् दुर्दर्शोहं कुयोगिनाम् The meaning of this verse is, O Narada, the Lord is speaking to Narada, I regret that during this lifetime you will not be able to see me anymore. Those who are incomplete in service, and who are not completely free from all material taints, can hardly see me. Now here the Lord is explaining to Narada that Narada is not yet freed from all material taints. That's why one cannot see in spite of all sincerity, sincere attempts and endeavours. So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, the personality of Godhead is described in the Bhagavad Gita as the most pure. In the 10th chapter, Param Brahma Param Dhama Pavitram Paramam Bhavan. Pavitram means pure. Paramam Bhavan Paramam Pavitram, Supreme pure, complete pure, 100% pure. And he is described also as the supreme and the absolute truth, Param Brahma. So there is no trace of a tinge of materiality in this person. Unlike our personality, right now, in the material world, there is a contamination of materiality in this person. So that is the categorization of this personality. There is a contamination of the illusory influence of the material energy in our consciousness, and that's why we have a material conception of our self, of everything. Whereas the Lord, even when he comes to this material world, He is 100% pure, completely spiritual. There's no tinge of any materiality in this personality. But he is giving us this materiality, the same materiality that the Lord gave us. Even though he appears like a person who is created being of this world, he appears like that, son of Devaki, or he appears in his incarnation as Matsyavatara, he appears as a fish, but he is not touched by the material energy. It's not a material form, it's not a material creation. He comes in his original transcendental form only, though he appears as required, whichever form he desires to appear, to incarnate, to give darshan to his devotees, to mitigate the problems, the sufferings of his devotees, Paritranaya sadhuna. So, therefore, it is said here, thus, one who has the slightest tinge of material affection cannot approach him. So, this is conversely also explained that the Lord doesn't have any tinge of materiality and those in this material world who have any tinge of material affection cannot approach him. Not possible. The beginning of devotional service starts from the point when one is freed from at least two forms of material modes, namely the modes of passion and ignorance. The result is exhibited by the signs of being freed from karma and lobha. Karma means lust, lobha means greed or covetousness. That is to say, one must be freed from the desires for sense satisfaction and the avarice for sense gratification. Generally material conception of life is I am seeking satisfaction of my senses and I am also desirous or greedy for getting more of sense enjoyment. These two things, kama and lobha, are the symptoms of rajas and tamas.

And there are examples by his activities, he has engaged many devotees, like Prahlad Maharaj, Dhruva Maharaj, so many others, in the transcendental service of the Lord. A pure devotee of the Lord, therefore follows in the footsteps of great devotees, like Narada Muni and Prahlad Maharaj, and engages his whole time in glorifying the Lord by the process of kirtana. So archana is the worship of the deity form, and it's always to be accompanied by kirtana, the glorification of the Lord, either by singing his holy, glorification of his holy name, or glorification of his activities or pastimes, like that. Such a preaching process is transcendental to all material qualities. So clearly, Srila Prabhupada is explaining, the advantage we have in the process of archana, kirtana, of course, Bhakti Yoga begins with Shravanam Kirtanam Vishnu, but of all the processes for a neophyte, especially in this age, archana is recommended. Either you directly worship, or if you are unable to worship, then you participate in the worship of the Lord in the temple. That's what you should do. In this way, you can actually very easily progress in Bhakti Yoga and come to the stage of perfection very quickly. Thank you very much.

In this session we will be discussing from the 31st verse of the 6th chapter of the 1st canto of Sriman Bhagavatam: अन्तर बहिष्च लोकाम स्त्रीन परियेमी असकंधित व्रतः अनुग्रहान महा विष्णोर अविघात गति क्वचित. The meaning of this verse is: Since then, by the grace of the Almighty Vishnu, I travel everywhere without restriction, both in the transcendental world and in the three divisions of the material world. This is because I am fixed in unbroken devotional service of the Lord. So this verse pertains to Narad Muni's describing to Vyasa Deva about his present life. As was explained in the previous verse, after the night of Brahma, next day when the creation began, Narad Muni appeared as a son of Brahma, but he appeared in the same transcendental body. He changed from his material body to a transcendental body when he quit his body in his previous life. After that, once he is in a transcendental body, there is no more change of body. So, just along with Brahma, he entered into Garbhodakshayi Vishnu's transcendental form. And during the night of Brahma, he remained there and he came out appearing as the son of Brahma. But this appearance is complete, just like Krishna appears as the son of Vasudeva and Devaki, like that. So, after that appearance, he is describing here, since then, by the grace of the Almighty Vishnu, Narad Muni is the pure devotee of the Supreme Lord. So, by the grace of the Supreme Lord, Almighty Vishnu, I travel, that means Narad Muni travels everywhere without restriction. Which all places does he travel? Both in the transcendental world and in the three divisions of the material world. So, that would be explained by Prabhupada in the purport. He travels everywhere, both in the spiritual world and all the divisions of the material world. Why? How is this possible? This is because I am fixed in unbroken devotional service to the Lord. How is it possible? Because Narad Muni is fixed up completely in unbroken devotional service of the Lord. That is described in the Sanskrit as Unbroken vow. Unbroken vow of devotional service.

#### Material World, Spiritual World, Vaikuntha Planets
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/7wUSRHAOCp8?t=257
**Verse References:** BG 9.4
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "And contains unlimited self-illuminated Vaikuntha planets."
**Summary:** This segment explains the three divisions of the material world, the spiritual sky with Vaikuntha planets, and the difference between living entities in the material and spiritual worlds, drawing from Bhagavad Gita.

In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, as stated in the Bhagavad Gita, there are three divisions of the material spheres. This entire material universe, there are three divisions: Urdhva Loka, the upper planetary systems; Madhya Loka, the middle planetary systems. We are in the middle planetary system on the earth planet. And downward, below the earth, that is Adho Loka. Now, beyond the Urdhva Loka, beyond the upper planetary systems of which the Brahma Loka is the topmost in this universe, there are the material coverings of the universe. This whole universe is like a shell, Brahma Anda. It's called Brahma Anda, egg-shaped, Anda, therefore. And outside this shell, there are seven layers of coverings. And above this universe with its coverings, outside that, is the spiritual sky. And the spiritual sky is described as unlimited in expansion. Material sky is limited within the universal shell, whereas the spiritual sky is spread throughout, unlimited expansion, and contains unlimited self-illuminated Vaikuntha planets. Now, Vaikuntha planets are spiritual planets, unlike the material planets within the material universe. And these Vaikuntha planets are inhabited by God himself, along with his associates, who are all eternally liberated living entities. There are living entities in this material world. There are living entities in the spiritual world.

#### Absolute Truth, Relative Truth, Material vs. Spiritual
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/lVBk_IkI5HY?t=184
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "Absolute Truth is Truth which is... Truth in all phases of time. Past, Present and Future."
**Summary:** The speaker defines Absolute Truth as unchanging and contrasts it with Relative Truth, which is subject to change in the material world, using the example of a person residing in a house.

The very opening verse, it is said by Vyasadeva, the author of the Bhagavatam, that I meditate upon Shri Krishna because he is the Absolute Truth. सत्यं परं धीमही. सत्यं परं सत्यं परं सत्यं is truth. परं there indicates Absolute Truth. So what is this Absolute Truth? Absolute Truth is Truth which is... Truth in all phases of time: past, present, and future. The Truth is always the Truth. It doesn't change. Relative Truth is Truth which is not true in all phases of time. Every Truth in the material world of some material object or material activity is a Relative Truth. If... To give an example, if I say such and such a gentleman is residing in a particular apartment or house. Now this statement is a Relative Truth because what happens with time, in course of time, that gentleman who's staying in a particular house, when he passes away, when he changes body, when he dies, then that statement, 'such and such a gentleman residing in the house,' is no longer true. Then we are to say he was residing, and when he died, he is no longer residing in the house, or even when he shifts from that residence due to whatever reason to another residence, then that statement, 'such a gentleman is residing in this house,' is no longer true. So like this, every statement we make about a material phenomenon in this world is a relative truth. It is relative to time, whereas the absolute personality of Godhead Krishna is absolute truth. He is always the Lord. He doesn't change his body. He doesn't change his position. His form, his name, his qualities, his forms don't change. You look at our own form, material body, it changes. They... He knows when you thought they... Hey, come on, your venom, Jara, anything material, it is constantly undergoing change. That's the...

#### yoga, devotional service, sense control, soul satisfaction
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=59
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "yoga system is helpful to actually control the senses but it is not effective in giving satisfaction to the soul"
**Summary:** Narada Muni explains that while yoga can control the senses, it doesn't provide soul satisfaction, which comes from devotional service.

In this session, we will be discussing from the 35th verse of the 6th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. We are continuing the conversation between Narada and Vyasa Deva. Towards the end of the chapter, a few more verses, the chapter will conclude. So the 35th verse is, the meaning of this verse is, it is true that by practicing restraint of the senses by the yoga system, one can get relief from the disturbances of desire and lust, but this is not sufficient to give satisfaction to the soul, for this satisfaction is derived from devotional service to the Personality of Godhead. So Srila Narada Muni is clearly explaining that the yoga system is helpful to actually control the senses, but it is not effective in giving satisfaction to the soul. Ultimately, we are always seeking satisfaction of the soul, though we do not know it, especially those in ignorance of the spiritual nature of the self. They are unaware that the satisfaction of the senses, mind, or intelligence is not satisfaction of the soul. I, the real person, am different from the body or the senses. I am different from the mind. I am different from my intelligence. I am spirit, so this spirit requires spiritual satisfaction, soul satisfaction. So that is explained very nicely by Srila Prabhupada in the purport: yoga aims at controlling the senses. This is one of the main purposes of practicing yoga, to control the senses. Generally, our senses are totally uncontrolled in the sense, with the idea that whatever the senses demand, we are simply busy satisfying those demands, but that is not the way of spiritual life. So in yoga practice, there is by practice of the mystic process of bodily exercise in sitting, thinking, feeling, willing, concentrating, facing, and setting away, meditating and, as beam bus into trance and in this one can control the senses. So this, they call it eight-fold yoga system, Ashtanga Yoga: yama, niyama, asana, pranayama, na para nayam, pratyahara, dharana, dhyana, samadhi. Samadhi is completely being merged into transcendence. But the scriptures also describe this method of controlling the senses through yoga practice, Ashtanga Yoga practice. About that, the scriptures are telling, the senses are considered like venomous serpents, and the yoga system is just to control them. Narad Muni is recommending another method for controlling the senses. What is that? The method of transcendental loving service of Mukunda, the Personality of Godhead, the system of Bhakti, the process of Bhakti. It is different than the Ashtanga Yoga process.

#### Ashtanga Yoga, devotional service, sense engagement, Krishna Consciousness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=338
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Ashtanga Yoga is denying the sense satisfaction, denying mind satisfaction, denying intellectual satisfaction all this by forcibly restraining the senses"
**Summary:** The speaker contrasts Ashtanga Yoga's artificial method of denying sense gratification with devotional service's positive engagement of the senses in spiritual activities.

By his experience, Narad Muni says that devotional service to the Lord is more effective and practical than the system of artificially controlling the senses. The method of Ashtanga Yoga is an artificial method. That means you have to force yourself against your natural way of living, whereby you engage your senses in sense satisfaction in some activity aimed at either satisfying the senses or the mind or the intelligence. So Ashtanga Yoga is denying the sense satisfaction, denying mind satisfaction, denying intellectual satisfaction, all this by forcibly restraining the senses, holding back the senses from their sense objects, holding back the mind, not indulging the mind or the senses or the intelligence, whereas what happens in devotional service? In the service of the Lord Mukunda. Mukunda means another name for Krishna. The senses are transcendentally engaged. This is the big difference. It is not stopping the senses, it is engaging the senses, but in a different way. What is that different way? Spiritually engaging them, transcendentally engaging them. That means we do spiritual activities in Krishna Consciousness. That is the system of Krishna Consciousness, the system of Bhakti. We engage the senses in spiritual activities, just like you may like to hear a very melodious Kirtan, Hare Krishna Kirtan. That is transcendentally engaging your ears and your mind and even your intelligence, or you may relish tasting nice Krishna Prasadam. That is engagement for the tongue, the mind, the intelligence, everything. So it is positive engagement. Bhakti is positive engagement, of course, in a specific type of activity, spiritual activity, and there are varieties, there is variety, ample variety of spiritual activities. In this way, if the senses are transcendentally engaged while serving Lord Mukunda, Lord Krishna, there is no chance of the senses being engaged in sense gratification, no chance. And the important point to notice, the senses want some engagement. They cannot be kept for long without any activity. That is artificial. To check them artificially is no check at all, because as soon as there is some opportunity for enjoyment, the serpent-like senses will certainly take advantage of it.

**Summary:** The speaker uses the examples of Vishwamitra Muni and Haridas Thakur to illustrate the difference between artificial sense control and the power of devotional service to overcome Maya.

And Prabhupada gives a nice example. There are many such instances in history, and they have been recorded in the Puranas, in the scriptures, just like the example is given of Vishwamitra Muni. He was a great king. He renounced his kingdom and all the wealth and the comforts, royal comforts, and he went away to a forest, a secluded place, and he was performing tapasya. But he, while practicing tapasya, Vishwamitra Muni became a victim to the beauty of Menaka. Whenever any great personality is very determined to perform tapasya, Indra, the king of heaven, he becomes very worried that this person who is doing tapasya may overtake me and replace me as the king of heaven. So Indra sends Apsaras to disturb the tapasya, and that's what exactly happened when Vishwamitra Muni was sitting in the forest and performing meditation. Indra sent one Apsara by name Menaka, and Menaka came and she allured Vishwamitra Muni, and Vishwamitra Muni became completely distracted from his tapasya. But the other example that is also given, a devotee of Lord Chaitanya Thakur, Haridas, he was allured at midnight by the well-dressed Maya. Maya Devi herself came to allure Haridas Thakur when he was sitting and chanting Hare Krishna. Still, she could not induce him into her trap. She could not do that. In fact, Maya Devi surrendered to Haridas Thakur and begged for the holy name from him. So a devotee who is engaged in devotional service cannot be allured by Maya because this is a superior engagement. This is explained in the Bhagavad Gita, param drishtva nivartate. If you want to stop the senses from being engaged in mundane sense activities, then you should engage the senses in devotional service, and such engagement is superior.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=736

**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes that pure devotional service is the topmost path to self-realization, superior to yoga, jnana, and karma, and that these other paths are dependent on bhakti.

You cannot be distracted by Maya. The whole idea is that without devotional service of the Lord, neither the yoga system nor philosophical speculation can ever become successful. Always yoga means karma, karma yoga, jnana, jnana yoga, tapasya, ashtanga yoga, they are different. Whenever the word yoga is suffixed to karma, jnana, or tapasya, then it means that you have to mix with devotional service. Now, pure devotional service of the Lord is without any tinge of or without any mixture of fruity work, mystic yoga, or speculative philosophy, without any mixture of karma, jnana, or tapasya, that without any mixture of that, pure devotional service is actually the foremost procedure for self-realization. This will be explained in detail in the later portions of the Bhagavatam. Such pure devotional service is transcendental in nature, and the systems of yoga and jnana are subordinate to such a process. Yoga and jnana are dependent on mixture of bhakti, whereas pure bhakti is independent of yoga, jnana, karma, everything else. When the transcendental devotional service is mixed with a subordinate process, it is no longer transcendental. It is called mixed devotional service. So all this will be explained by Sri Vyasadeva in the text later on, but for now Narada Muni is telling, bhakti can give complete satisfaction for the soul. Yoga can help in controlling the senses, but it cannot give satisfaction for the soul. Therefore, he is recommending bhakti over the process of yoga or even the process of jnana or even karma. So bhakti, pure devotional service, is the topmost.

So, generally people who are pious in this material world, they are interested in four goals of a civilized human being, mentioned in the Shastra: Dharma, Artha, Karma, Moksha. But Bhakti is greater than these four Purusharthas. Bhakti is called the Panchama Purushartha, the fifth goal of a human being, of a living being. So, when a devotee becomes attracted by Krishna and begins to render devotional service, automatically such a devotee loses interest in Dharma, Artha, Karma, Moksha. Those four Purusharthas don't interest the devotee anymore. Completely, the devotee rises above these four Purusharthas. Now, the next set of meanings that Lord Chaitanya explains. The word Brahma indicates the Samambonam, the absolute truth, which is greater than all other truths. In this material world, whatever we know as truth is called relative truth. And Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, is the absolute truth. What is absolute truth? Absolute truth is truth in all phases of time, under all circumstances, in all conditions. Whereas relative truth is not truth in all phases of time. It is the original identity, Brahma means the original identity, and there can be nothing equal to that absolute truth. So, there is a definition of this absolute truth as Brahma in the Vishnu Purana. It is stated there, I offer my respectful obeisances to the absolute truth, the Samambonam. He is the all-pervasive, all-increasing subject matter for the great yogis. He is changeless, and he is the soul of all, the soul of all souls, the super soul, the supreme soul. Actually, the proper meaning of the word Brahma is the Supreme Personality of Godhead, who is one without a second, and without whom nothing else exists.

Now, Krishna is realized through three processes, the Absolute Truth. Krishna means the Absolute Truth is realized through three processes: the process of philosophical speculation, the process of performing Ashtanga, you call it a mystic yoga process, and the process of devotional service. So Lord Chaitanya has learned this. So Lord Chaitanya is now explaining, although the words Brahma and Aatma indicate Krishna, their direct meanings refer only to the impersonal Brahma and the super soul respectively. Brahma means impersonal Brahman. Atma means the super-soul in the heart of every living being. So why the distinction is being made now is, because if one follows the path of philosophical speculation, Gyanamarga, the Absolute Truth manifests Himself as impersonal Brahman. That means through the Jnana Marga one cannot realize Krishna simply by following the Jnana Marga. The topmost possible realization of the Absolute Truth through Jnana Marga is only the impersonal Brahman. If one follows the path of Mystic Yoga, Ashtanga Yoga system, he manifests himself as a Supersoul. So through Ashtanga Yoga only the Paramatma can be realized, only the Paramatma. But through devotional service one realizes Krishna, the personality of Godhead Bhagavan. In the Bhagavatam it is explained there are three features: the Absolute Truth, the impersonal Brahman, the localized Paramatma or the Supersoul, and ultimately the personality of Godhead Bhagavan. So among these three features, realization of Bhagavan, the personality of Godhead is the highest realization and that includes the other two realizations of Brahman and Paramatma.

That's what happened to Dhruva Maharaj. It is said that Dhruva Maharaj has become a Bhikkhus and has begun to worship Supreme Lord Krishna. That's what happened to Dhruva Maharaj. He began to worship Supreme Lord Vishnu and Vishnu gave him darshan. Now when Vishnu gave darshan, Dhruva thought, I am doing all these austerities to ask from the Lord for what, a kingdom in this material world, that he compared to a piece of broken glass. He is looking for a piece of broken glass, foolishly, by doing devotional service, worshipping Vishnu. But when Vishnu appeared and gave him darshan, then he thought after seeing Vishnu, when I have got diamonds, why will I be interested in a piece of broken glass? So, Dhruva Maharaj told Vishnu, when Vishnu said, yes, what is the boon you want from me? So, Dhruva Maharaj said, when I obtained you, my dear Lord, I am not interested in asking any other benediction from you, I don't want any other benediction. It is like a person who has got diamonds. Why will he be interested? So, Krishna is so kind that when a devotee foolishly desires some material gain, Krishna gives himself to the devotee and he attracts the devotee so very much. The devotee completely forgets or considers the divine insignificant any other material gain that he might have been interested in before he began Bhakti. So this is Krishna's way of attracting a devotee who may not know the real goal of Bhakti but still nevertheless renders devotional service to Krishna even with a desire for some material gain.

So there it is said by the Devatas, O Lotus-eyed one, they are addressing the Supreme Lord Krishna. Those who think they are liberated in this life but are without devotional service to you are of impure intelligence. Although they accept severe austerities and penances and rise to the spiritual position, to impersonal Brahman realization, they fall down again because they neglect to worship your lotus feet. There has to be some engagement after liberation. If there is no engagement after liberation, due to inactivity, one becomes very much disturbed in the mind. And eventually, such a person, without taking shelter of Krishna's lotus feet, cannot engage in the spiritual process. This is the statement in the Bhagavatam. One cannot engage in spiritual activity. So what does the person do?

Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Devim Sarasvatim Vyasam Tato Jayam Udhirayet. In this session also we will continue discussion of the Atmarama verse. Lord Chaitanya tells a very nice story of how a hunter, cruel hunter, a very, very uncivilized person, how he became a great devotee by the association of Srila Narada Muni, the greatest devotee of the Lord. Once upon a time, the great saint Narada, after visiting Lord Narayana in the Vaikuntha, went to Prayag. Prayag is that holy place, Allahabad, where there is a sangam, a confluence of three rivers, Ganga, Yamuna and Saraswati. And it's a very, very holy place. And he saw a deer which was lying on the path through the forest, and this deer was pierced with an arrow. It had broken legs, and it was crying out of pain. That arrow had pierced its body, and it was crying out of pain. He went a little ahead and saw another boar which was pierced. It was pierced by a similar arrow. Its legs were also broken. It was also crying out in pain. And further he went, saw a rabbit also, same way it was suffering. With the arrow pierced, legs are broken, it is crying in pain. So Narada Muni, he was pained to see at heart. All these living. All these living beings are suffering so much. Then he saw a hunter hiding behind one tree. He was having so many arrows. And he was ready to kill more animals. This hunter was having a black complexion, a dark complexion. He had reddish eyes. And he appeared very, very fierce. He was like the superintendent of death. He was like the superintendent of death. Yamarath standing there with bow and arrows in his hands to kill so many more animals. Now Narada Muni, he left the path which was there in the forest. And he went to the hunter who was hiding behind a tree to kill more animals. And as soon as Narada Muni approached the hunter, so many animals, they started running away. The hunter, he wanted to chastise Narada Muni with abusive language, that you spoiled my whole arrangement for killing animals. But when Narada Muni came closer to the hunter, due to Narada Muni's divine association or divine presence, that hunter restrained his tongue and did not abuse Narada Muni. He said, oh great saintly person, why are you leaving the general path and you are approaching me in this forest? Simply by seeing you, all the animals I was hunting have now run away. You have disturbed my occupation. So Narada Muni replied to this hunter, I have come to you to clear one doubt that is there in my mind. So Narada Muni asked that hunter, those animals which are half killed, three animals I saw. I saw a deer, I saw a boar, I saw a rabbit. Were you the one who actually shot those arrows and half killed those animals? The hunter replied, yes. Narada Muni inquired from this hunter, why are you not killing those animals completely? You are half killing them by piercing one arrow which does not fully kill them. Why are you doing like this? Then the hunter replied to Narada Muni, my name is Mrigari. Mrigari means I am the enemy of the animals. My father taught me how to kill in this way, half kill animals by piercing one arrow. And this hunter is telling Narada, when I see animals suffer due to pain, then I become very happy. So Narada Muni told this hunter, can I beg from you one thing? The hunter said, yes. What do you want? You want the skin of some animals, tiger skin, deer skin, I can give you. Narada Muni said, no, no, no. I do not want any skin from you. I want to request you that kindly don't half kill animals. You kill them completely, fully kill them. Don't half kill animals. So the hunter asked, what's the difference between half killing and fully killing the animals? So Narada Muni replied that when you half kill the animals, they suffer so much more pain than if you were to fully kill the animals. See, as a hunter, your business is to kill animals. Now that's an offense on your part, killing animals. But if you unnecessarily give them so much more pain by half killing them, you incur very great sin. So this is Narada Muni's divine influence on the hunter.

But here, even though the combined heat of the two Brahmastras was like the Samvartaka fire, it was actually highly controlled. It is completely controlled. So he did not allow this heat to spread or this radiation to spread. He retracted both the Brahmastras and he knew the science perfectly. Arjuna knew the science and therefore he was able to retract both the Brahmastras by the knowledge of how to use that Brahmastra.

The 35th verse: Mainam Partharhasitratum Brahma Bandhum Imamjahi Yosav Anagasa Suptan Avadheen Nishi Balakan. The meaning of this verse is: Lord Sri Krishna said, "O Arjuna, you should not show mercy by releasing this relative of a Brahmana, Brahma Bandhu, for he has killed innocent boys in their sleep." Krishna is justifying punishing Ashwatthama appropriately because Ashwatthama has killed innocent boys in their sleep. He is not observing the rules of Dharma Yudha. And he is being referred to as Brahma Bandhu, relative of a Brahmana. He is not a Brahmana. By his actions, he has proved otherwise. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "The word Brahma Bandhu is significant." Ashwatthama being referred to as Brahma Bandhu is significant. A person who happens to take birth in the family of a Brahmana, but is not qualified to be called a Brahmana, is addressed as the relative of a Brahmana and not as a Brahmana. This is a very, very important point to be understood, that simply by birth in a Brahmin family, without qualification, nobody can become a Brahmana. Nobody can be called as a Brahmana. Brahmana is only if they are qualified, only if they have characteristics and qualities of a Brahmana.

#### brahmana, qualification, shastra

**Summary:** The speaker explains that the shastras state that a person with Brahmanical qualities should be accepted as a Brahmana regardless of birth, and conversely, one born in a Brahmin family without the qualities should not be considered a Brahmana.

This is the Shastric injunction, but it is not understood properly or not enforced properly in modern times. The Shastra enjoins that even if good qualifications are seen in a person born in a family other than that of a Brahmana, the qualified man has to be accepted as a Brahmana. Yesiyal lakshanam proktam. That whatever the qualities that are seen in a particular person, irrespective of his birth in some family. Let's say somebody is born in a Vaishya family, but the person displays all qualities of a Brahmana, he has to be accepted as a Brahmana. That's what it is telling. The Shastras say like that. Similarly, if a person born in the family of Brahmana is void of Brahmanical qualification, he must be treated as a non-Brahmana, or in better terms, a relative of a Brahmana, Brahmabandhu. So, without qualification, nobody should be addressed as a Brahmana. And, there is sometimes protest by the so-called Brahmanas. If somebody born in a Vaishya family is referred to as a Brahmana because the person is qualified as a Brahmana, the others will protest. Lord Shri Krishna, the supreme authority of all religious principles, the Vedas, has personally pointed out these differences. Krishna actually explains this in several places, in several occasions, in stances, that only by qualification, we can call somebody a Brahmana.

So continuing the purport, "Then murder by killing the five sleeping sons of Draupadi." This is murder. This is not like Kshatriya fights in a Dharma Yuga and kills the enemy. It is not like that. In that, there is no sin. It is not to be considered as murder, fighting in a Dharma Yuga. But here, the sleeping sons of Draupadi were killed by Ashwathama. And by this act of killing the sleeping sons of Draupadi, this Ashwathama dissatisfied his master Duryodhana. Duryodhana never approved of the heinous act of killing the five sleeping sons of the Pandavas. Now Duryodhana also was fighting the battle of Kurukshetra following the principles of Dharma Yuga. This is explained earlier by Krishna. Suptam means sleeping. One who is sleeping is not to be killed. So therefore, Ashwathama became an assaulter of Arjuna's family members, and thus he was liable to be punished by Arjuna. And therefore, Krishna tells Arjuna, "Now you must actually kill this aggressor Ashwathama. You should kill him."

It doesn't matter whether you are a man or a woman, matter whether somebody is born as the son of a Shudra or a daughter of a Vaishya, it doesn't matter. They can be trained up. Everyone, every human being at least, can be trained up to understand the ultimate aim of life is to become connected with Krishna. That's called yoga. That specific science of yoga is taught by Krishna in the Bhagavad Gita. In the fourth chapter, Krishna says, imam vivasvate yogam proktavanaham avyayam. Krishna is telling, I taught the science of yoga to vivasva, and now I am going to teach you. He is telling Arjuna that same science of yoga. So that science of yoga is that actually each one of us, every spirit soul, every living being is connected with Krishna, and that connection is called yoga, and therefore ultimately one has to learn about who am I, who is Krishna, what is my relationship?

#### Shabda Vedi, Maharaj Dasaratha, Ramayana, mistake, consequences
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/cgnQKK7lYx8?t=178
**Verse References:** —
