**Summary:** The speaker narrates the story of Maharaj Dasaratha and his mastery of Shabda Vedi, the art of hitting a target by sound, and how he accidentally killed a Brahmachari named Shravan Kumar, leading to negative consequences.

To target a particular person when you release a weapon. That is lost now. That science is lost. So in the Ramayana, it is said that Maharaj Dasaratha, the father of Lord Sri Rama used to control arrows by sound only. He could pierce his target with his arrow by only hearing the sound without seeing the object. So Srila Prabhupad explains, it is called Shabda Vedi. Just like I cannot see where is a bird, but the bird is chirping. And by Shabda Vedi, I can release an arrow. It will go wherever the bird is by the dint of the sound the bird is making. And it will go and kill that bird. So, this is called Shabda Vedi. Now Maharaja Dasharatha used it. He knew this science and he used it. And once he made a mistake of instead of killing an animal in the forest, he killed a boy, one Brahmachari. It is described in the Ramayana. Because that Brahmachari had come, he was taking his parents on a pilgrimage and they were old. He was carrying them in a palanquin and when they were thirsty on the way, so he stopped and he went to fetch water. So, he went looking for a water source and he found a pond with clear water. So, when he dipped that pot in the pond to get water, it made sound and this Dasharatha, was actually hiding. And when he heard that sound, he thought here is some animal that has come to drink water in the pond. So, he released an arrow aimed at whoever was actually making that sound while fetching water or drinking water. And the arrow went and actually pierced that Brahmachari. His name was Shravan Kumar. That is described in the Ramayana. And Shravan Kumar almost immediately was killed by the arrow released by Dasharatha. Then Dasharatha, after having released the arrow, when he heard a human being is crying out, then he went and saw, Oh, I have killed a Brahmachari. He never intended to kill a Brahmachari. No. But he mistook by the sound of that pot he was trying to fill. He mistook that sound to be the sound of an animal drinking water. And because he knew the science without seeing the target, He actually shot the arrow, Shabda Vedi, and it went and pierced that target. The Brahmachari who made that sound while filling the pot.

Because they were divine natured. So they should be ruling the people. Because they are divine natured. Not demoniac natured persons like Kauravas. So they were ruling. But when they came to know that Krishna has actually departed for his personal abode. Immediately they retired. Immediately they retired and went on Mahaprasthana. They renounced. Of course before renouncing they handed over charge of ruling to the grandson, Arjuna's grandson Parikshit Maharaj. So Yudhishthira handed over charge to Parikshit Maharaj. And all the five Pandavas they went away. Mahaprasthana. They keep walking while remembering the Supreme Lord. And in that consciousness of remembrance of the Lord they will quit the body. Whenever it is time to quit the body. They keep walking, walking, walking. So they are conscious of the ultimate goal is to prepare oneself to quit the body while remembering the Lord. And therefore when they learnt that Krishna has gone back to his abode and Narada had told you remain here on the earth till Krishna is here. And after that you go back to Krishna. Because they are all belonging to Krishna. They are associates of Krishna. Personal associates. So they go back to Krishna. They came for the sake of participating in Krishna's pastimes as Krishna's assistants. And they go back. This is the position of a pure devotee. So as pure devotees they never forget they teach us by their exemplary behavior. What is the proper goal in spite of studying these other subjects. They are not carried away by those skills. I will stop here.

The 45th verse is Saesha Bhagavang Dronaha Praja Rupena Vartate Tasyatmano Urdham Patnyaste Nanvagad Veerasu Kripi. The meaning of this verse is, He that is Dronacharya is certainly still existing, being represented by his son. His wife Kripi did not undergo a sati with him because she had a son. Gravapati is explaining the reason why Ashwatthama should not be killed. She is coming up with so many different arguments that here she is saying that she is not a good person. She is telling Dronacharya he died in the battle but he is still existing because he is represented by his son, Praja Rupena Vartate, and Dronacharya is referred out of respect by Draupadi as Bhagavan Dronaha, Saesha Bhagavata Dronacharya is referred out of respect by Draupadi as Bhagavan Dronaha, Saesha Bhagavata. So it is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport, the wife of Dronacharya, Krippi, is a sister of Krippacharya, a devoted wife, who is according to the revealed scripture, the better half of her husband, is justified in embracing voluntary death along with her husband, if she is without issue. But in the case of the wife of Dronacharya, she did not undergo such a trial, because she had her son, the representative of her husband. So Srila Prabhupada explains, a widow is a widow only in name, if there is a son of her husband existing. So in either case, Ashwathama was a representative of Dronacharya, and therefore killing Ashwathama would be like killing Dronacharya. That was the argument.

#### Praja, Father-Son Relationship, Vedic Culture, Widow
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Cgn6KZhkQxY?t=497

**Summary:** The speaker explains the concept of 'Praja' (offspring) and the father-son relationship in Vedic culture, emphasizing that a son represents the father, and a woman with a son is not considered a widow even if her husband is deceased.

Nobody else can excel him. So she is telling he is extraordinarily powerful personality, Dronacharya. Saesha Bhagawan Drona. Praja roopena vartate. He is still existing. Praja. In the form of Praja. Praja means offspring, son or daughter. So one who is born of the father is called Praja. Now without father there is no possibility of any birth taking place, either son or daughter. So one who gives birth, Prajayate. Praja is the product of the body of the father. That's what Prabhupada explains. The father's body is actually present in the form of the son or daughter, Praja. The Shastra says, Yatha yoni yatha bijam. Father is the bijam. The seed is given by the father. And just like you sow a seed in the ground, then a huge tree comes up. So the seed itself is generated by the tree. But that seed again grows up to be a tree. So the seed is tree later on. Similarly, the seed is put by the father in the womb of the mother, implanted. And when you sow a seed in the ground, you take care for it to properly grow. Similarly, the seed is sown in the womb of the mother, and the mother takes care of the seed and becomes a big body and comes out. So this is the process of birth. In one sense, the seed and the tree there is no difference. Similarly, there is no difference between the son and the father. No difference. The seed of the father and the father himself, there is no difference. So Dronacharya is still present in the form of his son, Ashwathama. So according to Vedic culture, this is very important to understand. A woman who has got a son, even if her husband is dead, she is not considered a widow. Widow, which actually means a woman who doesn't have a husband, who has lost her husband, husband is dead. But if the husband's representative is there, the son, then the woman is not a widow.

#### dharma, scriptural injunctions, renunciation, duty, contradictions
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/DuSFo72mcIE?t=289
**Verse References:** BG 18
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Whenever somebody tries to refer the scriptures, then in certain circumstances, to apply the scriptural injunction, it is difficult."
**Summary:** The lecture explores the difficulty in applying scriptural injunctions, using the example of a sanyasi's duties and the apparent contradictions within the scriptures.

So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says that Arjuna was perplexed because Ashwatthama was to be killed as well as spared according to different scriptures cited by different persons. This is a fact. Whenever somebody tries to refer the scriptures, then in certain circumstances, to apply the scriptural injunction, it is difficult. In the 18th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, it is explained that for somebody who is a sanyasi, who is in the renounced order of life, there are no duties to be performed. No duties to be performed because he is completely renounced. He is simply engaged in devotional service to Krishna, exclusively dedicated for that. That is the meaning of renunciation. At the same time, Shastra says that activities which are of the nature of yajna, dana and tapa should never be given up under any circumstances. For a civilized human being, in all stages, one should never stop performing sacrifice because sacrifice is specifically activity meant for pleasing the Supreme Lord. So, in that way, we can understand sacrifice should never be given up. Though, material activities, or material duties even, a sanyasi has got no material duties. A brahmachari has got duties, a grihasta has got duties, a vanapurasta has got duties, but a sanyasi has no material duties. So, it is difficult to understand whether a sanyasi should perform any activities, or not do any activities at all. So, like this, in the scriptures, there are injunctions which seemingly are contradictory in certain circumstances, in certain situations where one has to apply. Different people will give different circumstances, cite different shastras and give different rulings.

#### knowledge vs. devotion, purification, material contamination, spiritual satisfaction
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5PXy_ny0POc?t=570
**Verse References:** —

That material enjoyment, yes, we can have to whatever extent we can get some material pleasure by the means of the body, but as spirit soul, we are not meant to enjoy materially. #### soul's satisfaction, material vs. transcendental happiness, temporary vs. eternal bliss
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5PXy_ny0POc?t=772
**Verse References:** BG 5.22

The Bhagavatam raises this point: what ensures that there is complete satisfaction for the soul? The satisfaction of the soul, of the real self, that is to be considered. The satisfaction of the soul is never possible by any material pleasure, material means, material methods, material pleasures, material arrangements. It never even touches the soul in any way. So therefore, people who are seeking real happiness, they are frustrated when they make different arrangements for enjoying materially, or they seek material happiness, and they never are satisfied within their heart, never are satisfied. So this point is explained in the Bhagavad Gita: yehi samsparishya ja bhoga dukha yonaya evate aadyantavan takaunteya nateshu ramate budhah. One more verse that explains what is the nature of transcendental happiness: sukham aatyantikam yatta buddhikrahyam atindriyam. These material senses are useless for experiencing any any spiritual happiness or transcendental happiness. So material pleasure is simply a sensation, and it is a temporary thing. It is also called chapala sukha, momentary happiness, and it eventually leads to miseries only, whereas transcendental happiness completely pure bliss, and it is never momentary. So I will stop here. A non-devotee himself doesn't know that he belongs to Krishna. So how will he understand others connection with Krishna. He will never understand by himself if he continues to be in material existence. So therefore to bring about the welfare of all the citizens, all the people of this world, Krishna vanquished the rule of the company of Duryodhana and established the rule of Maharaja Yudhishtira. He also wanted to protect Maharaja Pariksit who was lying in the embryo for the same reason. The successor to Yudhishtira is Pariksit Maharaj, the only surviving descendant in the entire Pandava era. He did not like the idea that the world should be without the Pandavas, the ideal family of devotees. Apandavam idam kartum. Apandavam. This Ashwathama wanted to finish off the last life in the Pandava family so that the world will be without any descendants of the Pandavas, but Krishna did not like that because he wanted pure devotees to rule the world and continue to successively rule. Their descendants who are also pure devotees should successfully rule the world. That's what Krishna wants. And even preaching Krishna consciousness is the only way to do that.

Asuras generally want to go against the authority established by the Supreme Lord in this world, in the material world. When the Lord appears as Rama, Narasimha, Varaha, Vamana, any of the transcendental incarnations of the Lord, or even as Krishna, then he performs so many activities which are impossible to be performed by any person of this world, by any human being, or even any devata. They cannot perform. Now, in the tenth canto of the Srimad Bhagavatam, it is clearly explained that Krishna exhibited extraordinary power even when he was lying on the lap of his mother Yashoda as a small child, infant, not child, infant, just born. Say about ten days after Krishna took birth, he was attempted to be killed by one Putana. But when Putana came to breastfeed Krishna with her breast milk, she had severe deadly poison on her breast. And Krishna, he sucked out her life. When she tried to feed him poison through her breast milk, Krishna sucked out her life air. So, it is not possible for anybody of this world to suck out another person's adult's life air, prana, suck out the prana. And instantaneously, Putana died. Instantaneously.

Each line has got the word Pankaja, means a lotus. So the translation of this verse, My respectful obeisances are unto you, O Lord, whose abdomen is marked with a depression like a lotus flower. Pankaja Nabhaya Who are always decorated with garlands of lotus flowers. Pankaja Maline Whose glance is as cool as the lotus. Pankaja Netraya And whose feet are engraved with lotuses. Pankajangraye Angri means the bottom of the feet. Pankajangraye And whose feet are engraved with lotus flowers.

So this specific example is given to neophyte devotees just to convince them that material hankerings and spiritual advancement go ill together. They don't go together. Material opulence and spiritual advancement don't go together unless one is able to see everything as spiritual in relation with the Supreme Lord. One must always distinguish between spirit and matter. A neophyte devotee should not artificially try to see the spirit and matter as one and the same. A neophyte devotee should make distinction between what is spirit and what is matter, should make a distinction. A spiritual master like Sanatana Goswami, although personally able to see everything as spiritual, set this example for us only because we have no such spiritual vision. We don't have spiritual vision at the present moment to understand that even matter being emanation from Krishna is also ultimately spiritual only, but then such a vision is not possible for a neophyte devotee in the beginning of Devotional Service. So what happens is, what happens.

#### material advancement, civilization, spiritual advancement, material miseries, Anartha, Krishna consciousness, pure devotees
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/JCME3k_SHaQ?t=795
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required."
**Summary:** The speaker concludes by stating that material advancement is an unwanted thing (Anartha) that leads to entanglement and misery, and encourages listeners to give it up and embrace Krishna consciousness under the guidance of pure devotees.

When somebody advances materially, material advancement is civilization. Such material advancement is a great stumbling block for spiritual advancement. The more one becomes materially advanced, the more one becomes puffed up, and consequently, such a puffed up person cannot make spiritual advancement even if such a person takes to chanting Hare Krishna, because the chanting will be done without the sincere feeling. That is not possible for a materially intoxicated person. Such material advancement entangles the living being in the bondage of material body followed by all sorts of material miseries. See, material advancement comes with a price. What is that? With material advancement, there is entanglement and entanglement means material miseries. So, this has to be carefully understood. So, therefore, in Sanskrit, material advancement is called Anartha, unwanted things, unwanted. Actually, this is so. This is a fact. Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required. So, Prabhupada gives an example that in the present context of material advancement, one uses lipstick at a cost of 50 cents and there are so many unwanted things which are all products of material conception of life. So many material possessions people have, but that makes them only entangled, and subsequently, they have to face so many unwanted miseries. Everybody understands miseries are unwanted, but that's a result of possessing so many material things which are actually Anartha. So, Prabhupada's instruction is give up this business of material advancement and take to Krishna consciousness under the guidance of pure devotees.
